title: Re: Anyone able to help me with basic Visual C++ 2005?
content:
A) Never used the Property Manager, the class view shows you classes in the graph layout
B) They must be in directories VC knows about. Right-click on the project in Solution Explorer, and go to properties. Under C/C++ you'll see 'additional include directories'. An extra directories are in here, relative to the project directory. Make sure you make changes for both debug and release if you're planning to compile a release build at some point.
C) A solution holds projects. For example, you can have a 'MySweetGame' solution that has the game project, the engine project and the map editor project. I'm not sure what you mean by 'their relation to the actual scripts themselves'.
D) They are all basically templates for creating default, almost empty project of different types. Choosing CLR will create a blank project set up for .NET, Win32 will create a blank project for Windows (optionally with the WinMain function put in and precompiled headers set up) and General creates a blank project not configured for anything specifically - so a blank DOS window-type project.------------------

title: Re: Anyone able to help me with basic Visual C++ 2005?
content:
Wow, VC++ sounds needlessly complicated - give me GCC/G++ and a Makefile anyday [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]

LoG, I think you should try to figure out how to enable "simple" mode to start off with, all these IDEs try to generate as much code as possible for you, which really confuses beginners (I speak from experience) and if you do use it you often end up with a slow, bloated program.

When I started learning C, I spent the first six months being confused by all the options in the Borland IDE I was using, and once I figured out how to switch all that stuff off suddenly it became really easy to start coding [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]
